content.description: Boulder up on to a ledge to gain a crack system. Follow the narrowing crack to the top.
content.protection: Singles .75-#3. The crack is very irregular inside, so be prepared to fiddle with the gear to get it set well. Currently no anchors, but solid trees on top for a TR anchor.
content.location: About 20' left of the wide corner and just to the right of the blue "Kelsey" graffiti.

content.description: Start just right of the easy corner, using small edges to move up to some horizontals. After placing some gear, move up past the huge creaky flake. I yarded on this flake quite a bit before leading the route and it didn't fall off. However, it flexes quite a bit and is huge, so I didn't pull on it while climbing. It is easy to avoid, so you might just want to do that. The upper part of the route is fairly juggy, but it is quite a ways down to your last piece, so keep it together. There is a flake you can place a questionable C4 #.75 behind, as well as a pass-thru that can be threaded.
content.protection: I gave this route a PG-13 due to the flexy flake and for decking potential due to the questionable gear higher up on the route. This is not a lead for beginners. I placed a #4, #1, and #.75 C4. There may be more opportunities for gear, but I felt safe with those pieces. No anchors at the top at this time, but with a good amount of webbing (20'+) you can set up a solid tree TR anchor.
content.location: Just right of the prominent wide corner.

content.description: Slopey crimps lead up to a good horizontals. Once past the horizontals, climb pockety jugs to the top.
content.protection: #1 C4, a medium nut, and a sling for a pass-thru at the top. No anchors, but trees can be used for a TR anchor.
content.location: Left of the prominent wide corner, and immediately left of the blue "Kelsey" graffiti.

content.description: This wall faces west, so has morning shade and afternoon sun. It is about 25' tall, with lots of trees at the top for anchors. Once you are done climbing, you can hike back to the parking lot on the Post Oak Trail at the top of the cliff line. A helmet is strongly recommended as many of the lines have lots of potentially loose holds.
